div1.p: Carter's obituary describes his many accomplishments, lists his publications, and compares Carter, Reed, and Gorgas, to famous soldiers, jurists, and statesmen of Virginia.

div1.head: Obituary of Henry Rose Carter, by B. J. Lloyd, [1925] [Enclosed in C0312008]
div1.p:
If lent please return to
L.A. Carter
The Westmoreland,
Washington, D. C.

Bolivar J Lloyd M. D.
Asst Surgeon General
U.S. Public Health Service

Assistant Surgeon General Henry R. Carter died at 4:18 this
morning at the Westmoreland Apartments of this city after a some-
what prolonged illness of general failure of vital powers. There
were with Dr. Carter at the time of his death, his daughter Laura
Armistead Carter, his sister Miss Mary Clayborne Carter of North
River Plantation, Virginia, Assistant Surgeon General B. J. Lloyd
of the U. S. Public Health Service and Mrs. Essie Hill, the nurse
who has been with him throughout his last illness. Dr. John Minor
his physician arrived a few minutes after Dr. Carter had passed
away.

Dr. Carter is survived by two sons, Dr. Henry R. Carter, Jr.,
a prominent physician of Birmingham, Ala., Mr. Edward Champ Carter
of Baltimore, Md., a brother, Mr. Charles Harrison Carter of Port-
land, Oregon, a sister Mrs. Nancy Carter Redd of Ashland, Va., in
addition to his daughter Miss Laura and his sister Miss Mary C. Car-
ter previously mentioned.

The name of Dr. Henry Rose Carter is one of the most illustri-
ous in that comparatively small group of the world's great medical and
sanitary specialists. He was one of the very few men who have dem-
onstrated entirely new principles and applied them in the product-
ion of practical results.

Dr. Carter was born in Clifton Plantation, Carolina County, Vir-
ginia, August 25, 1852. He was commissioned in the U. S. Marine Hos-
pital Service, now the Public Health Service on May 5, 1879. He served

as Chief Quarantine Officer of the Island of Cuba from Jan. 1899 un-
til August 1900 and as Chief Quarantine Officer of the Isthmian Canal
Commission from May 1904 until February 1905 when he became Director
of Hospitals of the Isthmian Canal Commission, serving in this capaci-
ty from March 1905 until September 1909. He served at different times
as Sanitary Supervisor to the Peruvian Government and as a member of
the Yellow Fever Council of the International Health Board of the Rock-
effeller Foundation up until the time of his death.

Among the most notable of his sanitary and scientific achieve-
ments may be mentioned, - the determination of the period of extrinsic
incubation of yellow fever, a foundation on which the brilliant work of
Walter Reed and his commission rested and for which Dr. Carter was nom-
inated for the Nobel prize by the distinguished English physician and
sanitarian, Major Sir Ronald Ross.

He was the founder of the present maritime quarantine system of
the United States. Dr. Carter served in and dominated many outbreaks
of yellow fever epidemics in the Southern States, including that of
MacHenry, Mississippi, the first outbreak of this disease which was
controlled during the summer months; inaugurated the quarantine systems
of Cuba and the Canal ports.

He enunciated the principles relating to the bearing of the im-
pounding of great bodies of waters on the production of malaria, a mat-
ter in which the economic future of many parts of our Southern States
is bound up.

He inaugurated control measures for malaria in the extra can-
tonment areas of army camps in malarial regions during the world
war. He was a member of many scientific bodies relating to medi-
cine and hygiene, both American and foreign. He formulated the
doctrine of the control of the yellow fever bearing mosquito as the
sole method necessary for the elimination of endemic centers of this
disease.

He was intimately associated with Gorgas and Reed throughout
the greater parts of their careers, particularly in the work, study,
and control of yellow fever. It is doubtful if modern science re-
cords a like example of men of kindred sympathies and almost common
birth whose labors in the same field of endeavor yielded such notable
results.

Carter and Reed were native Virginians. Gorgas passed the form-
ative years of his life in the State of Virginia and while he never
knew Dr. Carter until their manhood, they cooperated with splendid
comradeship in the study and conquest of yellow fever, the scourge
of the tropics, which formerly so often invaded our own country. It
is well known that the greatest engineering feat of the ages,- the
completion of the Panama Canal could not have been accomplished with-
out the work of these men.

The Commonwealth of Virginia that boasts great soldiers like
Washington, Jackson, Lee; jurists like Wythe, Marshall and Roane and
- 4 -
great statesmen like Jefferson, Madison and Monroe, rejoices that
she has a claim on three of the greatest benefactors of our day,
Carter, Reed and Gorgas.

Among the numerous writings which Dr. Carter has contributed
to scientific medicine during a long and useful career may be men-
tioned the following:

list.item:
1. Note on the Interval between Infecting and Secondary
Cases of Yellow Fever from the Records of the Yellow Fever at Or-
wood and Taylor, Miss., in 1898.

2. Period of Incubation of Yellow Fever in Man. (Planned
with (1) and (3) and written about the same time -- the trilogy
forming a complete work). Pub. in Medical Record, Feb. or March
190. Original manuscripts deposited in Army Medical Museum as
permanent record.

3. A note on the Spread of Yellow Fever in Houses. Extrin-
sic Incubation. Medical Record, June 15, 1901.

4. Some Characteristics of Stegomyia Fasciata Which Affect
its Conveyance of Yellow Fever. Medical Record, May 14, 1904.

5. Notes on the Sanitation of Yellow Fever and Malaria from
Isthmian Experience. (Pan American Scientific Congress, Santiago
de Chile, 1908. Med. Record, July, 10, 09).

6. Immunity to Yellow Fever. (Pan American Scientific Con-
gress 1915. Pub. Annals of Tropical Medicine and Parasitology,
Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, April 1916).

7. Spontaneous Disappearance of Yellow Fever by Failure of
the Human Host. (Read before the Society of Tropical Medicine &
Hygiene, (London) June 1917).

8. Mechanism of the Spontaneous Elimination of Yellow Fever
from Endemic Centers. Journal of Tropical Medicine and Parasitol-
ogy, March 1920. Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine.

div1.p:
General Gorgas said of Dr. Carter, that, “he was one of the
great pioneers in malaria and yellow fever work.” Walter Reed, in
- 5 -
a personal letter said, “Dr. Carter's work in Mississippi did more
to impress me with the importance of an intermediate host in yellow
fever than everything else put together.”

Dr. Carter was graduated in medicine from the University of
Maryland and entered the Marine Hospital Service, May 5, 1879. In
the fall of the same year, he saw his first case of yellow fever. In
1890, Dr. Carter had proposed the disinfection of vessels from Cuban
and Mexi can ports at the port of departure, so that the time en route
to the port of entry after such disinfection could count as a part of
the “quarantine period” for yellow fever, and by so much, lessen the
time of the detention in quarantine. How this method has been de-
veloped to its present status is a matter of history and its saving
to commerce is incalculable.

Reed and his co-workers in their memorable report on the “Trans-
mission of Yellow Fever”, made the following statement: “we were much
impressed by the valuable observations made in Orwood and Taylor during
the year 1898 by Surgeon Henry R. Carter. We observed that the members
of the Ywellow Fever Commission of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medi-
cine, Doctors Durham and Meyers, to whom we had the pleasure of submit-
ting Dr. Carter's observations, have been equally impressed by their
importance.” Other observations made by us confirmed Dr. Carter's con-
clusions, thus pointing, as it seemed to us to the presence of an in-
termediate host such as the mosquito, as being the probable vector of
the causative agent of yellow fever.

Kitisato, the famous Japanese scientist of his work in simplify-
ing quarantine says, “It is at once scientific and practical, rep-
resenting the only advance in maritime quarantine since the time of
the Venetians.”

For many months, prior to his death, although long since retired
and feeble in body, but vigorous in mind, Dr. Carter has worked on an
unusually complete history of yellow fever, a work in which has taken
him into many fields of literature and history in many languages, and
even in many dialects. His one hope was to live until this great work
should be completed. Three days before he was stricken with what
proved to be his last illness, he had so far completed this work that
it can be easily finished by others, and this task will be undertaken
by Dr. Wade Hampton Frost and by his daughter, Miss Laura, who has served with him and aided him in
this last great research.

Surgeon General and Mrs. Cumming and members of the corps of
the Public Health Service stationed in Washington have been in con-
stant touch with him during his last illness.

The funeral services will take place at 10:00 Wednesday morning.
These will be first at the Westmoreland, and later at St. Margaret's
Church. Archdeacon Sterling Claiborne of Sewanee, Tennessee and Rev.
Dr. Smith of St. Margaret's Church will conduct the funeral services.

Relatives, friends and officers of the Service will accompany
the body on the noon train, Wednesday, to Ashland, Virginia, its final
resting place, beside his wife, who died a number of years ago.
